channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Pope Setting Up Commission on Clerical Child Abuse
item.description: Pope Francis and his closest advisers appear to want to be seen to be tackling the sexual abuse issue with greater firmness than in the past.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO and ALAN COWELL

item.title: Gunmen Kill American Teacher in Benghazi
item.description: The victim, a chemistry teacher in an English-language school, had been jogging when attacked, according to Libyan security officials and the director of his school.
item.dc:creator: By SULIMAN ALI ZWAY and KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: The Lede: Reports From the Central African Republic’s ‘Darkest Days’
item.description: As the United Nations authorized African and French military forces to deploy to protect civilians, reporters and aid workers reported from a country descending into deeper tides of blood.
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTINE HAUSER

item.title: U.S. Official Tells Ukraine’s Protest Leaders to Find a Solution
item.description: Victoria Nuland, a senior State Department official, effectively told them that President Viktor F. Yanukovich must remain in power despite demands for his ouster.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Protesters occupying Kiev's City Hall rested on Thursday.

item.title: In United Arab Emirates, Satirical Video Lands Five Men in Jail
item.description: The harsh reaction to the 20-minute mocumentary is likely to embarrass the Emirates at a time when it is advertising itself as an international destination for culture.
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD

item.title: As Central African Republic Convulses, Security Council Votes to Strengthen Force There
item.description: Fighting broke out in Bangui, the capital, just before the United Nations Security Council approved a resolution to expand a force in the country.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER and SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:description: Wounded civilians lay on the floor of a hospital on Thursday in Bangui, the capital of the Central African Republic.

item.title: U.S. Charges Dozens of Russian Diplomats and Spouses With Medicaid Fraud
item.description: A criminal complaint unsealed in Manhattan says the Russians, who are protected by diplomatic immunity, illegally obtained $1.5 million in benefits.
item.dc:creator: By BENJAMIN WEISER

item.title: Paul Aussaresses, 95, Who Tortured Algerians, Dies
item.description: General Aussaresses stunned France in 2000 when he asserted that he tortured and summarily executed dozens of prisoners during his country’s war in Algeria four decades earlier.
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS MARTIN
item.media:description: General Aussaresses said that summary executions were policy.

item.title: Biden Faults China on Foreign Press Crackdown
item.description: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. raised the issue as Beijing withholds accreditation for journalists from The New York Times and Bloomberg.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER

item.title: Kerry, Seeking to Nudge Along Peace Talks, Offers Netanyahu Security Proposal
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry discussed security arrangements that could be put in place in the West Bank and the Jordan Valley, a move that seemed to signify a more active American role in Israeli-Palestinian talks.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Iran Takes Charm Offensive to the Persian Gulf
item.description: Iran’s foreign minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif, is touring the region, trying to undo years of tensions with Arab neighbors, which harbor deep suspicions of Tehran.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:description: Iran’s top diplomat, Mohammad Javad Zarif, left, met Wednesday with the ruler of Dubai, center, and its foreign minister.

item.title: The Lede: Iran’s State TV Attacks Jon Stewart, and Emulates Him
item.description: Another sign of Iranian glasnost: a youth-oriented program on state television recently mocked the same network’s coverage of the nuclear negotiations in Geneva.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: December 5
item.description: Women riding two-wheeled scooters in the Indian capital.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Women riding two-wheeled self-balancing scooters in New Delhi.

item.title: Yemen’s Defense Ministry Is Attacked on 2 Fronts
item.description: A car bomb detonated at one entrance to the building, and attackers on foot opened fire at another, leaving at least 20 people dead, news reports said.
item.category: Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula
item.dc:creator: By NASSER ARRABYEE and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Smoke billowed from Yemen's Defense Ministry after an assailant drove a car packed with explosives into the complex on Thursday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Air Pollution Shrouds Eastern China
item.description: Shanghai, which generally has better air quality than northern cities like Beijing, is experiencing some of the worst pollution in recent memory.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: The authorities in Shanghai warned children and the elderly to stay indoors Thursday as concentrations of the most harmful air pollutants exceeded 10 times the level deemed safe by the World Health Organization.

item.title: India Ink: U.S. Evangelicals, Indian Expats Teamed Up to Push Through Modi Visa Ban
item.description: The author, who participated in the efforts to deny the Gujarat chief minister a United States visa in 2005, retraces the roots of that campaign, which has taken on new importance as Mr. Modi rises.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By ZAHIR JANMOHAMED
item.media:description: Narendra Modi, chief minister of Gujarat, speaking at a public rally in Jammu city, Jammu and Kashmir, on Sunday.

item.title: Letter From Europe: A Division in Rugby, and in England
item.description: The shadings of English rugby reach beyond its image of mass pugilism and point to a persistent north-south divide in the country.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: New Zealand's Manu Vatuvei was tackled by a group of Australian players during the the Rugby League World Cup final last week. The match was played at Old Trafford, Manchester United’s stadium, and drew a record crowd of almost 75,000.

item.title: Lens Blog: Raising Coca and Hopes in Bolivia
item.description: Marcelo Pérez del Carpio returned to the Bolivian countryside to find migrants and peasants abandoning traditional crops for the promise of quick cash with coca.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID GONZALEZ
item.media:description: Maria, left, Andreina, center, and Julia prepared lunches to sell in the morning. Residents of Challa sometimes complement their incomes by selling supplies along the road.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Lawyers Describe Abuse Outside Chinese Activists’ Trial
item.description: Lawyers representing a group of Chinese activists on trial in Jiangsu Province say they and the daughter of one defendant were harassed and roughed up outside the court on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Tense Thailand Is Quiet on King’s Birthday
item.description: The antigovernment protests that have left five people dead paused to allow celebrations for the 86th birthday of King Bhumibol Adulyadej.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Covering Biden in Beijing, and Becoming the Story
item.description: When Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. visits China, he does not let the serious matters at hand dampen his mood.
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY
item.media:description: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. , left, with his Chinese counterpart, Li Yuanchao, Thursday in Beijing.

item.title: To Expand Reach, Retailers Take Aim at Hispanic Shoppers
item.description: Macy’s will join media companies, political parties and other major retailers in showering attention on the country’s fast-growing Hispanic population.
item.dc:creator: By ELIZABETH A. HARRIS
item.media:description: Thalía Sodi, a Mexican pop star who will have a new line at Macy’s in 2015.

item.title: DealBook: Europe Sets Big Fines in Settling Libor Case
item.description: The European Union fined a group of global financial institutions a combined 1.7 billion euros ($2.3 billion) on Wednesday to settle charges that they colluded to fix benchmark interest rates.
item.dc:creator: By CHAD BRAY and JACK EWING
item.media:description: Joaquín Almunia, Europe’s commissioner for competition policy, announced details of the case on Wednesday in Brussels.

item.title: Sudanese Detainee to Be Sent Home From Guantánamo
item.description: The prisoner, Noor Uthman Mohammed, has finished the portion of his sentence he was required to serve, the Pentagon announced.
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: Militants Attack Iraqi Police, Then Take Hostages
item.description: The attackers staged an assault on a police building in the northern city of Kirkuk, and at least 22 people were taken hostage on Wednesday, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
